abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sao Paulo Third Land
            Management Project for Brazil were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: organized beneficiary farmers, having
            witnessed the impact of technological change and better land
            management practices on their lands, are now poised to
            exploit the productive benefits they were promised as a
            result. Further, the micro-catchments is an effective forum
            for rural organization and planning important for more
            complex productive and other activities and a building block
            for exploring and facilitating territorial and/or regional
            development approaches. First-cycle micro-catchments
            projects need to build installed capacity to more rapidly
            and successfully execute follow-up operations. The
            inevitable result is the short time available under the
            initial project to capitalize on and consolidate acquired
            knowledge and experience. Scaling-up should be balanced with
            further innovation under follow-on operations. There is a
            need to continuously 'sell' the project rationale,
            objectives and results to senior authorities, budget
            officials and policy makers across the political spectrum,
            in all related agencies, and beyond the rural sector. Visits
            by authorities to the project area/micro-catchments to
            demonstrate project activities and impact, and meet
            beneficiaries and local collaborators, are recommended.
